entries.question: How do credits work?
entries.answer: Starter Credits load $10 into your wallet. Spend them like cash and top up whenever you need more runs.

entries.question: Do they expire?
entries.answer: No expiry. Balances roll forward month to month and sync across every teammate with access.

entries.question: What if a generation fails?
entries.answer: Failed renders auto-refund within minutes. You only pay when the job completes successfully.

entries.question: What are member discounts?
entries.answer: Spend $50 in 30 days to save 5%, $200 to save 10%. Savings apply automatically to every eligible run.

supplementalFaq.question: Can I use Sora 2 in Europe?
supplementalFaq.answer: Direct access is invite-only. MaxVideoAI provides paid access to Sora 2 rendering from Europe via our hub.

supplementalFaq.question: Do videos have watermarks?
supplementalFaq.answer: No. Renders produced through MaxVideoAI are delivered without watermarks.

items.question: How does "price before you generate" work?
items.answer: The price chip updates as you change engine, duration, and resolution. You are charged only on success.

items.question: What do iterations mean?
items.answer: Iterations generate 1-4 variants in a single run using the same settings.

items.question: Why do duration/resolution/aspect options differ by engine?
items.answer: Each engine exposes its own caps, so the UI only shows what that engine supports.

items.question: When is audio available?
items.answer: Audio appears only on engines that support it, with a toggle when available.

items.question: Where do I find past runs?
items.answer: Open /jobs for your history and /examples for curated prompts you can reuse.

hero.title: Compare all AI video models in one workspace
hero.subtitle: Compare every AI video engine available in MaxVideoAI.
hero.body: MaxVideoAI lets you compare every serious AI video engine side-by-side: Sora 2, Veo 3.1, Pika 2.2, Kling, Wan, MiniMax and more. Check real examples, specs and live pricing so you can pick the right model for each shot, not guess from a waitlist demo.

paragraphs: Each engine in this catalog is wired into the MaxVideoAI workspace with monitored latency, price tracking, and fallbacks. We add models as soon as providers open real capacity‚Äînot waitlist demos‚Äîso you know what can ship to production today.
Pick an engine to see the prompt presets, duration limits, and current route we use to keep renders flowing, then duplicate it into your own workspace.

cards.title: When to choose Sora
cards.body: Reach for Sora 2 or Sora 2 Pro when you need cinematic physics, character continuity, or audio baked directly into the render. These tiers cost more per second but deliver hero-quality footage.

cards.title: When to choose Veo
cards.body: Veo 3 tiers provide precise framing controls and tone presets, plus fast variants for iteration. They are ideal for ad cuts, b-roll, and campaigns that demand consistent camera moves.

cards.title: When to choose Pika or MiniMax
cards.body: Pika 2.2 excels at stylised loops and social edits, while MiniMax Hailuo 02 keeps budgets low for volume runs. Both complement Sora and Veo when you need fast alternates or lightweight briefs.

cards.title: When to choose Nano Banana
cards.body: Storyboard or edit photoreal stills before jumping into motion. Nano Banana shares the same wallet and prompt lab, so you can prep Veo/Sora shots with text-to-image or reference edits.

cta.title: Need a side-by-side?
cta.comparisonLabel: Sora vs Veo vs Pika comparison guide
cta.middle: for detailed quality notes, price ranges, and timing benchmarks, then clone any render from the
cta.after: to start with a proven prompt.

faq.question: How pricing is calculated
faq.answer: We show an estimated $/s for each engine based on current public pricing and our internal normalization. Final cost can vary by provider tier and generation settings.

faq.question: Why max duration differs per engine
faq.answer: Max duration depends on provider limits, tier (fast/pro), and generation mode (text-to-video, image-to-video, extend/continue). We display the latest known limits per engine.

faq.question: What Compare mode shows (specs + prompts + examples)
faq.answer: Compare mode opens a side-by-side page with key specs, strengths, and example renders. When available, it uses the same prompt template so you can judge outputs more fairly.

faq.question: How to use model pages (full details)
faq.answer: Each model page includes full specs, supported modes (T2V/I2V/V2V), and a prompt section you can copy to reproduce results or iterate quickly.

faq.question: How often data is updated
faq.answer: We update model limits and pricing references as providers change their published info and as we test new versions. If something looks off, the model page notes the last refresh.

meta.title: AI Video Engines ‚Äî Compare Sora, Veo, Pika | MaxVideoAI
meta.description: Compare availability, latency, and compliance routes for Sora 2, Veo 3, Pika, and MiniMax engines in Europe.

hero.title: Run AI Video Generators in Europe ‚Äî Sora 2, Veo 3, Pika & More
hero.intro: MaxVideoAI keeps cinematic text-to-video engines compliant, monitored, and production-ready for European teams. Use this hub to understand availability, compare creative trade-offs, and launch projects with the right guardrails from day one.
hero.secondary: Not sure which model to pick? Read our {{article:comparison article}}.

sections.title: Sora 2 availability and alternatives
sections.body: Sora 2 remains a staged rollout, so MaxVideoAI handles the verification trail, regional compliance, and predictive routing when capacity spikes. Producers can benchmark storyboards against {{sora:Sora 2 reference projects}} and switch to Sora 2 Pro presets or Veo 3 sequences when turnaround speed matters more than frontier fidelity. We document prompt structures, footage approvals, and post-production best practices so every brief stays aligned with OpenAI review criteria while still shipping on time. Regional producers also receive weekly availability notes covering audio support, frame length, and compliance traceability for regulated sectors.

sections.title: Veo 3: cinematic text-to-video for creators
sections.body: Veo 3.1 bridges the gap between storyboard accuracy and polished motion, especially when social or advertising deliverables need voice-over sync. Our routing keeps latency predictable and lets directors compare the fast preset with the longer-run tier before booking studio time. Review the latest guardrails, aspect ratios, and narration-ready examples on the {{veo:Veo 3.1 overview}} or tap the Fast variant when iteration speed outranks audio or frame count. We also surface a change log inside the workspace so editors can see when motion controls, audio fidelity, or policy notes adjust between releases.

sections.title: Pika 2.2 for fast social content
sections.body: When teams need playful loops or short-form edits, Pika 2.2 delivers multi-aspect outputs at a fraction of the budget. MaxVideoAI exposes curated presets so editors can jump from vertical reels to square product shots without leaving the workspace. Compare text-to-video and image-to-video modes side-by-side on our {{pika:Pika quickstart guide}} and reuse prompt banks that have already been cleared for brand-safe campaigns. Daily QA passes flag style drift or artefacts so you know when to regenerate, upscale, or hand off to animators for refinement.

sections.title: How MaxVideoAI routes Fal.ai engines
sections.body: Fal.ai powers the multi-engine routing backbone behind MaxVideoAI, letting us burst to capacity while surfacing a consistent interface to creative leads. Our orchestration layer keeps prompts portable, logs every render, and exposes diagnostics so you know when to retry or hand off to another engine like {{veoFast:Veo 3.1 Fast}} or {{hailuo:MiniMax Hailuo}} for stylised outputs. Teams also gain access to rate cards, audit trails, and regional compliance notes in one workspace, and automated playbooks explain how to escalate priority or swap render regions when demand peaks.

comparison.title: Compare the top video generators
comparison.intro: Whether you need frontier fidelity or budget-friendly loops, MaxVideoAI keeps each engine ready for production workloads.

cards.label: Sora 2
cards.title: Fidelity-first
points: Frontier video model with native audio
Strict review loop, longer queue times
Ideal for hero campaigns and cinematic briefs

cards.label: Veo 3.1
cards.title: Cinematic speed
points: Bridges storyboard fidelity with fast iteration
Switch between standard and fast queues
Audio-ready for interviews, ads, and explainers

cards.label: Pika 2.2
cards.title: Rapid social loops
points: Fast text or image to video renders
Ideal for reels, teasers, and playful concepts
Budget-friendly credits for experimentation

faq.question: Does MaxVideoAI support European billing for Fal.ai engines?
faq.answer: Yes. We process invoices in EUR or GBP and map them to Fal.ai usage so finance teams can reconcile spend without US subsidiaries or prepaid card workarounds.

faq.question: How quickly can teams launch a Sora 2 project?
faq.answer: Most creative teams start prompting within two business days. We keep onboarding templates ready and provide fallback Veo or Pika presets while Sora access is finalised.

faq.question: Can I monitor model changes without refreshing documentation?
faq.answer: The MaxVideoAI workspace highlights latency, output limits, and policy updates in real time, so producers know when to retry or pivot to alternative engines.

cta.body: Looking for sequenced prompt recipes? Read the latest guides on the {{blog:MaxVideoAI blog}} for branded storytelling walkthroughs and engine updates.

hero.title: The MaxVideo AI blog.
hero.subtitle: News on engines, customer stories, prompt guides, and price-before best practices. Subscribe in-app to get updates in your queue digest.

intro.lead: MaxVideoAI‚Äôs journal covers everything we learn while routing frontier video engines for real production teams. We document prompt patterns, pricing changes, latency shifts, and the workflows that keep agencies on schedule when models rotate. Every story is written from live usage‚Äînot a press release.

cards.title: Model deep dives
cards.body: Comparisons and capability notes for Sora 2, Veo 3, Pika 2.2, MiniMax Hailuo 02, and the engines queued next in our workspace.

cards.title: Workflow tactics
cards.body: Sequenced prompting, audio integration, and pricing guardrails that help teams ship branded stories without wasting credits.

cards.title: Customer stories
cards.body: How studios and marketers in Europe and North America deploy the same brief across multiple engines and keep review cycles moving.

faq.title: Blog FAQ

items.question: How often do new posts ship?
items.answer: We publish every week (and sometimes twice a week) as engines shift. Subscribe in the workspace to get a digest when new coverage lands.

items.question: Can I suggest a topic or request coverage?
items.answer: Yes‚Äîsend topics to press@maxvideo.ai and include reference renders if you can. We prioritize stories that help production teams stay current.

items.question: Where can I find release notes?
items.answer: Feature-level updates live in the product changelog, and API updates post inside the developer docs. The blog covers higher-level workflows.

faq.footnote: Need more detail? Email press@maxvideo.ai with your request and we‚Äôll route it to the right producer.

hero.intro: This video was generated with {engine} on MaxVideoAI ‚Äî discover how to create similar renders below.

seo.title: Render breakdown
sentences: This AI-generated video showcases {promptStyle} and ships straight from our public Examples playlist.
{engineName} handled this render inside MaxVideoAI, delivering {durationLabel} at {aspectRatioLabel} with {audioState}.
The footage highlights consistent motion, crisp lighting, and natural reflections so creative and product teams can judge how the model behaves.
Prompt styling keeps {promptTone} cues that you can remix or extend with image references, narration, or upscaling.
Use the engine card, pricing link, and blog resources below to compare models or start a similar run in your workspace.

hero.title: Quiet confidence for AI video teams.
hero.subtitle: MaxVideo AI is the independent hub for AI video production. We route to the right engine for every shot, price before you generate, and keep your team in control without vendor lock-in.

paragraphs: We believe professional teams deserve clarity before they hit render. That means price transparency, reliable routing, and shared context between creatives, producers, and stakeholders.

Independence matters: we stay neutral across engines, integrate with Sora 2, Veo 3.1, Veo 3 Fast, Pika 2.2, MiniMax Hailuo 02, Hunyuan Image, and rotating betas, and list trademarks only to describe compatibility.
The product is engineered for teams that need precision without noise. Quiet UI, premium defaults, precise controls, and price-before chips that keep finance in the loop.
about.note: Trademarks and service marks are property of their respective owners. MaxVideo AI stays independent so you can stay current without switching platforms.

hero.title: Contact the team.
hero.subtitle: Need support, enterprise onboarding, or press information? Send a note and we‚Äôll reply within one business day.

terms.title: Terms of service
terms.intro: These terms constitute the current valid User Agreement.

sections.heading: 1. Overview
sections.body: These Terms govern your use of MaxVideo AI. By accessing the service you agree to the obligations below.

sections.heading: 2. Accounts
sections.body: You are responsible for maintaining account security and ensuring teammates comply with these Terms.

sections.heading: 3. Usage & Compliance
sections.body: Use MaxVideo AI only in compliance with applicable laws, respect licensing limits, never upload illegal or infringing assets, and do not attempt to generate prohibited or unsafe content. We may review, block, or remove renders and suspend access when videos violate these Terms or our policies.

sections.heading: 4. User Content & Generated Media
sections.body: User uploads (photos, logos, reference footage, prompts) remain your property. We may store, process, and display uploaded assets solely to produce the requested text-to-video or image-to-video render and to deliver the workspace features you enable. For every piece of generated media, you grant MaxVideoAI a worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free, transferable, and sublicensable license to host, reproduce, index, display, and otherwise use the videos to operate the service, improve routing and models, run safety reviews, and showcase Examples galleries, template pages, or other marketing placements. You may mark renders as private inside your workspace or request delisting/desindexation by contacting support if a privacy toggle is unavailable, and we will honor the request. You retain ownership of your prompts, uploads, descriptions, and brand assets, while MaxVideoAI retains ownership of the platform, interfaces, transformations, and technical improvements built atop the service.

sections.heading: 5. Billing
sections.body: Wallet charges apply only to successful renders. Refunds are issued automatically for failed jobs.

sections.heading: 6. Liability
sections.body: MaxVideo AI is provided as-is. We limit liability to the maximum extent permitted by law.

privacy.title: Privacy policy
privacy.intro: Highlights of our privacy practices. Final legal copy will live here.

sections.heading: 1. Data we collect
sections.body: Workspace details, usage metrics, and billing information needed to deliver the service.

sections.heading: 2. How we use data
sections.body: Operate routing, improve product quality, and communicate critical updates.

sections.heading: 3. Storage & security
sections.body: We store data in encrypted systems with least-privilege access. Render assets auto-expire per workspace policy.

sections.heading: 4. Sharing
sections.body: We only share data with underlying engine providers when routing renders. We never sell customer data.

sections.heading: 5. Your choices
sections.body: Request export or deletion any time via support@maxvideo.ai. Admins control retention windows.

pika-text-to-video.description: Pika 2.2 handles stylized prompts or uploaded stills in one card ‚Äî perfect for quick loops and product explainers.

sora-2.description: OpenAI Sora 2 handles cinematic narratives with lip-sync and audio - ideal for hero renders.

sora-2-pro.description: Sora 2 Pro unlocks higher resolutions, synced dialogue, and image-to-video control for top-tier productions.

veo-3-1.description: Veo 3.1 now handles direct prompts or reference stills. Swap between text-to-video and image-to-video without leaving the queue.

veo-3-1-fast.description: Veo 3.1 Fast now handles quick text prompts or single-image animations with optional audio.

veo-3-1-first-last.description: Upload first and last frames, describe the bridge, and toggle between Veo 3.1 and Veo 3.1 Fast for the transition.

minimax-hailuo-02-text.description: Hailuo 02 Standard handles stylized text prompts or animated reference stills with prompt optimiser support.

kling-2-5-turbo.description: Kling 2.5 Turbo lives in one card with Pro text, Pro image, and Standard image-to-video modes for cinematic shots or budget loops.

wan-2-5.description: Wan 2.5 handles 5 or 10 second clips with optional background audio plus prompt expansion when you need extra detail.

wan-2-6.description: Wan 2.6 merges text, image, and reference-to-video in one card with multi-shot prompting and 720p/1080p tiers.

meta.title: {left} vs {right} ‚Äî Specs & Pricing | MaxVideoAI
meta.titleFallback: AI video engines ‚Äî Specs & Pricing | MaxVideoAI
meta.description: Compare {left} vs {right} on MaxVideoAI with identical prompts, key specs, and a scorecard across 11 criteria.
meta.descriptionFallback: Side-by-side comparison of AI video engines with MaxVideoAI metrics and guidance.

hero.intro: This page compares {left} vs {right} on MaxVideoAI using the same prompts, side-by-side renders, key specs, and a scorecard across 11 criteria. Use it to pick a winner fast ‚Äî then open each engine profile for full specs and prompt examples.

scorecard.title: Scorecard (Side-by-Side)
scorecard.subtitle: Scores reflect quality and control on MaxVideoAI across 11 criteria.

labels.placeholder: Placeholder example ‚Äî prompt render coming soon

keySpecs.title: Key Specs (Side-by-Side)
keySpecs.subtitle: Compare key AI video model specs side-by-side (pricing, inputs, resolution, duration, aspect ratios, audio, and core controls). This is a high-level snapshot ‚Äî see the full engine profile for the complete feature set and prompt examples.

showdown.title: Showdown (same prompt)
showdown.subtitle: Side-by-side renders from the same prompt on MaxVideoAI. Prompts are identical; outputs may vary by model.
showdown.note: Showing up to 3 prompt pairs for clarity.
showdown.footer: This side-by-side AI video comparison uses identical prompts to highlight differences in motion, realism, human fidelity, and text legibility. For full specs, controls, and more prompt examples, open each engine profile.

faq.title: FAQ
faq.subtitle: Quick answers about {left} vs {right} on MaxVideoAI (pricing, modes, specs, and why results differ).
faq.pricingDiff: Pricing varies by engine and settings (duration, resolution, audio). Currently, {left} starts at {leftValue} vs {right} starts at {rightValue}.
faq.outputPending: {label}: data is still being validated for one or both engines.
faq.a1: {left} and {right} are AI video generation engines available on MaxVideoAI. This page compares them side-by-side using the same prompts, key specs, and performance data shown above.
faq.a2: It depends on your workflow. Use the scorecard and the ‚Äúsame prompt‚Äù showdowns to compare prompt adherence, motion realism, human fidelity, and text legibility ‚Äî then open each engine profile for full details.
faq.a3: Pricing varies by engine and settings (duration, resolution, audio). Currently, {left} starts at {leftValue} and {right} starts at {rightValue} (see ‚ÄúPricing (MaxVideoAI)‚Äù for details).
faq.q4: What are the biggest differences between {left} and {right}?
faq.q5: Do they support Text-to-Video / Image-to-Video / Video-to-Video?
faq.a5: On MaxVideoAI: Text-to-Video is {t2vLeft} vs {t2vRight}; Image-to-Video is {i2vLeft} vs {i2vRight}; Video-to-Video is {v2vLeft} vs {v2vRight}. Some fields may still be under validation.
faq.q6: Do they support First/Last frame or references?
faq.a6: First/Last frame is {firstLeft} vs {firstRight}. Reference image/style is {refImgLeft} vs {refImgRight}; Reference video is {refVidLeft} vs {refVidRight}.
faq.q7: What are the max resolution, duration, and aspect ratios?
faq.a7: Max output is {resLeft} / {durLeft} for {left} and {resRight} / {durRight} for {right}. Supported aspect ratios include {arLeft} vs {arRight} (see Key Specs for the full list).
faq.q8: Do they support audio generation and lip sync?
faq.a8: Audio output is {audioOutLeft} vs {audioOutRight}. Native audio generation is {audioGenLeft} vs {audioGenRight}, and lip sync is {lipLeft} vs {lipRight} (some fields may still be under validation).
faq.a9: No. MaxVideoAI exports are watermark-free (‚ÄúWatermark: No (MaxVideoAI)‚Äù).
faq.q10: Why do results look different with the same prompt?
faq.a10: Even with identical prompts, models interpret instructions differently and use different training data and generation strategies. That‚Äôs why the Showdown section exists: same prompt, side-by-side outputs.
faq.q11: Where can I find full specs, controls, and more prompt examples?
faq.a11: Open the full engine profiles for complete specs, controls, and more prompts: /models/{leftSlug} and /models/{rightSlug}. You can also browse more outputs in the engine galleries.
